2.text:
Tonight, I can report to the
American people and to the world

6.text:
that the United States has
conducted an operation that

9.text:
killed Osama bin Laden,
the leader of al Qaeda,

13.text:
and a terrorist who's
responsible for the murder of

15.text:
thousands of innocent
men, women, and children.

21.text:
It was nearly 10 years ago that
a bright September day was

24.text:
darkened by the worst attack on
the American people in our history.

29.text:
The images of 9/11 are seared
into our national memory --

33.text:
hijacked planes cutting through
a cloudless September sky;

38.text:
the Twin Towers
collapsing to the ground;

41.text:
black smoke billowing
up from the Pentagon;

44.text:
the wreckage of Flight 93 in
Shanksville, Pennsylvania,

49.text:
where the actions of heroic
citizens saved even more

55.text:
And yet we know that the worst
images are those that were

60.text:
The empty seat at
the dinner table.

63.text:
Children who were forced to grow up
without their mother or their father.

67.text:
Parents who would never know the
feeling of their child's embrace.

76.text:
leaving a gaping
hole in our hearts.

79.text:
On September 11, 2001,
in our time of grief,

87.text:
We offered our neighbors a hand,
and we offered the wounded our blood.

92.text:
We reaffirmed our
ties to each other,

95.text:
and our love of
community and country.

98.text:
On that day, no matter
where we came from,

101.text:
what God we prayed to, or what
race or ethnicity we were,

106.text:
we were united as
one American family.

110.text:
We were also united in our
resolve to protect our nation

114.text:
and to bring those who committed
this vicious attack to justice.

120.text:
We quickly learned that the
9/11 attacks were carried out by

123.text:
al Qaeda -- an organization
headed by Osama bin Laden,

126.text:
which had openly declared war
on the United States and was

130.text:
committed to killing innocents in
our country and around the globe.

134.text:
And so we went to war against al
Qaeda to protect our citizens,

142.text:
Over the last 10 years, thanks
to the tireless and heroic work

146.text:
of our military and our
counterterrorism professionals,

150.text:
we've made great
strides in that effort.

152.text:
We've disrupted terrorist
attacks and strengthened our

157.text:
In Afghanistan, we removed
the Taliban government,

159.text:
which had given bin Laden and
al Qaeda safe haven and support.

163.text:
And around the globe, we worked
with our friends and allies to

166.text:
capture or kill scores
of al Qaeda terrorists,

169.text:
including several who were
a part of the 9/11 plot.

174.text:
Yet Osama bin Laden avoided
capture and escaped across the

181.text:
Meanwhile, al Qaeda continued to
operate from along that border

184.text:
and operate through its
affiliates across the world.

189.text:
And so shortly after taking
office, I directed Leon Panetta,

193.text:
the director of the CIA, to make
the killing or capture of bin

197.text:
Laden the top priority of
our war against al Qaeda,

200.text:
even as we continued our broader
efforts to disrupt, dismantle,

207.text:
Then, last August, after years
of painstaking work by our

211.text:
intelligence community, I was
briefed on a possible lead to

216.text:
It was far from certain, and
it took many months to run this

221.text:
I met repeatedly with my
national security team as we

224.text:
developed more information about
the possibility that we had

226.text:
located bin Laden hiding within
a compound deep inside Pakistan.

232.text:
And finally, last week, I
determined that we had enough

235.text:
intelligence to take action, and
authorized an operation to get

239.text:
Osama bin Laden and
bring him to justice.

243.text:
Today, at my direction, the
United States launched a

247.text:
targeted operation against that
compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan.

253.text:
A small team of Americans
carried out the operation with

261.text:
They took care to avoid
civilian casualties.

264.text:
After a firefight, they killed
Osama bin Laden and took custody

270.text:
For over two decades, bin Laden
has been al Qaeda's leader and

274.text:
symbol, and has continued to
plot attacks against our country

280.text:
The death of bin Laden marks the
most significant achievement to

283.text:
date in our nation's
effort to defeat al Qaeda.

287.text:
Yet his death does not
mark the end of our effort.

290.text:
There's no doubt that al Qaeda
will continue to pursue attacks

294.text:
We must -- and we will -- remain
vigilant at home and abroad.

300.text:
As we do, we must also reaffirm
that the United States is not --

304.text:
and never will be --
at war with Islam.

308.text:
I've made clear, just as
President Bush did shortly after

312.text:
9/11, that our war
is not against Islam.

315.text:
Bin Laden was not
a Muslim leader;

318.text:
he was a mass
murderer of Muslims.

320.text:
Indeed, al Qaeda has slaughtered
scores of Muslims in many

326.text:
So his demise should be welcomed
by all who believe in peace and

332.text:
Over the years, I've repeatedly
made clear that we would take

335.text:
action within Pakistan if we
knew where bin Laden was.

341.text:
But it's important to note that
our counterterrorism cooperation

344.text:
with Pakistan helped lead us to
bin Laden and the compound where

350.text:
Indeed, bin Laden had declared
war against Pakistan as well,

354.text:
and ordered attacks against
the Pakistani people.

360.text:
and my team has also spoken with
their Pakistani counterparts.

365.text:
They agree that this is a good and
historic day for both of our nations.

369.text:
And going forward, it is
essential that Pakistan continue

373.text:
to join us in the fight against
al Qaeda and its affiliates.

378.text:
The American people did
not choose this fight.

381.text:
It came to our shores, and
started with the senseless

388.text:
After nearly 10 years
of service, struggle,

391.text:
and sacrifice, we know
well the costs of war.

396.text:
These efforts weigh on me every
time I, as Commander-in-Chief,

400.text:
have to sign a letter to a
family that has lost a loved

402.text:
one, or look into the eyes of
a service member who's been

408.text:
So Americans understand
the costs of war.

412.text:
Yet as a country, we will never
tolerate our security being

415.text:
threatened, nor stand idly by
when our people have been killed.

420.text:
We will be relentless in defense
of our citizens and our friends

426.text:
We will be true to the values
that make us who we are.

430.text:
And on nights like this one, we
can say to those families who

433.text:
have lost loved ones to al Qaeda's
terror: Justice has been done.

440.text:
Tonight, we give thanks to the
countless intelligence and

443.text:
counterterrorism professionals
who've worked tirelessly to

448.text:
The American people
do not see their work,

453.text:
But tonight, they feel the
satisfaction of their work and

456.text:
the result of their
pursuit of justice.

459.text:
We give thanks for the men who
carried out this operation,

463.text:
for they exemplify the
professionalism, patriotism,

466.text:
and unparalleled courage of
those who serve our country.

470.text:
And they are part of a
generation that has borne the

472.text:
heaviest share of the burden
since that September day.

476.text:
Finally, let me say to the
families who lost loved ones on

480.text:
9/11 that we have never
forgotten your loss,

484.text:
nor wavered in our commitment to
see that we do whatever it takes

488.text:
to prevent another
attack on our shores.

491.text:
And tonight, let us think back
to the sense of unity that

498.text:
I know that it has,
at times, frayed.

502.text:
Yet today's achievement is a
testament to the greatness of

505.text:
our country and the determination
of the American people.

510.text:
The cause of securing our
country is not complete.

513.text:
But tonight, we are once again
reminded that America can do

517.text: whatever we set our mind to.

519.text:
That is the story
of our history,

522.text:
whether it's the pursuit of
prosperity for our people,

525.text:
or the struggle for equality
for all our citizens;

529.text:
our commitment to stand
up for our values abroad,

532.text:
and our sacrifices to make
the world a safer place.

537.text:
Let us remember that we can do
these things not just because of

540.text:
wealth or power, but because
of who we are: one nation,

546.text:
under God, indivisible, with
liberty and justice for all.

555.text:
And may God bless the
United States of America.
